Create C# apps using SQL Server on RHEL

1 Set up your environment
2 Create C# application with SQL server
3 Make your C# app up to 100x faster

In this section, you will get SQL Server 2017 running on RedHat Enterprise Linux. After that you will install the necessary dependencies to run .NET Core.

Step 1.1 Install SQL Server

Note: To ensure optimal performance of SQL Server, your machine should have at least 4 GB of memory.

  1. Register the Microsoft Linux repository

     sudo su
 curl https://packages.microsoft.com/config/rhel/7/mssql-server.repo > /etc/yum.repos.d/mssql-server.repo
 exit

  2. Install SQL Server

     sudo yum update
 sudo yum install mssql-server

  3. Setup your SQL Server

     sudo /opt/mssql/bin/mssql-conf setup

     Microsoft(R) SQL Server(R) Setup

 To abort setup at anytime, press Ctrl-C.

 The license terms for this product can be downloaded from http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=746388 and
 found in /usr/share/doc/mssql-server/LICENSE.TXT.

 Do you accept the license terms? If so, please type YES:
 Please enter a password for the system administrator (SA) account:
 Please confirm the password for the system administrator (SA) account:

You now have SQL Server running locally on RHEL machine! Check out the next section to continue installing prerequisites.

Step 1.2 Install .NET Core on RHEL 7.2

If you already have .NET Core installed on your machine, skip this step. Install .NET Core using the following commands.

You also need to ensure that your system supports enabling software collections via the scl tool.

  1. Enable the .NET Core Channel. For help registering your machine to get access to the channel see Chapter 1 of the .NET Core Getting Started Guide. 
    subscription-manager repos --enable=rhel-7-server-dotnet-rpms
  2. Install scl-tools 
    yum install scl-utils
  3. Install .NET Core 
    yum install rh-dotnetcore11
  4. Enable the .NET Core software collection 
    scl enable rh-dotnetcore11 bash

    You have successfully installed .NET Core on your RHEL machine. You now have everything you need to start writing your C# apps with SQL Server!

Go to step 2

Have Questions?

Happy to help! You can find us on GitHub, MSDN Forums, and StackOverflow. We also monitor the #SQLServerDev hashtag on Twitter.
